title: Olympic Winter Games
description: How much do you know about the Winter Olympics and their thrilling sports?

questions.question: In which year were the first Winter Olympic Games held?
questions.explanation: The first Winter Olympic Games were held in Chamonix, France, in 1924. Sixteen nations participated in 16 events across 6 sports.

questions.question: Which figure skater won gold medals at both the 1984 and 1988 Winter Olympics?
questions.explanation: East German figure skater Katarina Witt won consecutive Olympic gold medals in 1984 (Sarajevo) and 1988 (Calgary), becoming one of only three women to achieve this feat.

questions.question: Which country has won the most total medals in Winter Olympic history?
questions.explanation: Norway leads all nations in Winter Olympic medals with over 400 total medals. The country excels particularly in cross-country skiing, biathlon, and ski jumping.

questions.question: What is the luge?
questions.explanation: The luge is a winter sport where athletes ride a small sled feet-first down an ice track at speeds exceeding 90 mph (140 km/h). It has been an Olympic sport since 1964.

questions.question: Which city hosted the 2014 Winter Olympics?
questions.explanation: The 2014 Winter Olympics were held in Sochi, Russia. They were the most expensive Olympics ever at the time, costing approximately $51 billion.

questions.question: In which Winter Olympic sport do teams sweep the ice with brooms?
questions.explanation: Curling involves sliding granite stones on ice toward a target, while teammates sweep the ice with brooms to control the stone's speed and direction. It has been an Olympic sport since 1998.

questions.question: Which speed skater won five gold medals at the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics?
questions.explanation: Viktor Ahn (born Ahn Hyun-soo) won three gold medals in short track speed skating at Sochi 2014, competing for Russia. He had previously won gold for South Korea in 2006.

questions.question: When did snowboarding become an Olympic sport?
questions.explanation: Snowboarding made its Olympic debut at the 1998 Nagano Winter Games. Ross Rebagliati of Canada won the first ever Olympic snowboarding gold medal in giant slalom.

questions.question: How many athletes ride in a bobsled in the largest bobsled event?
questions.explanation: The four-man (or four-person) bobsled is the largest bobsled event at the Winter Olympics. The crew consists of a pilot, brakeman, and two pushers.

questions.question: Which country's 1980 Olympic ice hockey team was known as the 'Miracle on Ice'?
questions.explanation: The US men's ice hockey team, made up of amateur and college players, defeated the heavily favored Soviet Union team 4-3 at the 1980 Lake Placid Olympics in what is known as the 'Miracle on Ice.'

questions.question: What is the Nordic combined event?
questions.explanation: The Nordic combined is a winter sport that combines ski jumping and cross-country skiing. Athletes first compete in ski jumping, and then race in cross-country skiing.

questions.question: Which Winter Olympic sport involves athletes performing aerial twists and flips on skis?
questions.explanation: Freestyle skiing aerials involves athletes skiing down a steep ramp (kicker), launching into the air, and performing acrobatic maneuvers including twists and flips before landing.

questions.question: Which city will host the 2026 Winter Olympics?
questions.explanation: The 2026 Winter Olympics will be held in Milan and Cortina d'Ampezzo, Italy. It will be the first time Italy hosts the Winter Games since Turin in 2006.

questions.question: What is the skeleton in Winter Olympics?
questions.explanation: The skeleton is a winter sliding sport where athletes ride a small sled head-first down a frozen track. Athletes reach speeds of over 80 mph (130 km/h) while lying face down.

questions.question: Which male figure skater won three consecutive Olympic gold medals from 1920 to 1928?
questions.explanation: Swedish figure skater Gillis Grafstrom won gold medals at the 1920, 1924, and 1928 Olympics, making him one of the most successful figure skaters in Olympic history.
